localizedDescriptions.en: A persistent and managed list of any combination of archetypes that will support the accurate recording of a Care plan.
Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.

Name in structured format.
The prefix or title used by the subject.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Mr', 'Mrs', 'Ms', 'Dr', 'Lord'

localizedDescriptions.en: Given / personal / first name.
Middle name or names.
Family name or Surname.
Additional term used following a person name.

annotations.comment: e.g. 'Snr'

localizedDescriptions.en: FHIR telecom details.
Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.
The communication form is phone.
The communication form is fax.
The communication form is email.
The communication form is URL.
The communication form is pager.
The communication is SMS.
The communication form is other.
The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
The purpose of the contact point.
Home contact details.
Work contact details.
Temporary contact details.
Old contact details.
Mobile contact details.
Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. Contacts are ranked with lower values coming before higher values.
Details about the location of a person, physical building or landmark.
An unstructured address line representing all relevant street-level or post-box details that would support the identification of a location.

annotations.comment: Occurrences for this data element is set to 0..* to allow one or more free text 'Address line' data elements to represent the huge variety of ways that ‘street-level' details may need to be recorded within the context of a specified 'Town'. Multiple address lines can be represented in a template, renamed as 'Address line 1', 'Address line 2,' etc. For example: '7A/52 Davis Street' or 'Apartment 7A' as Address line 1 with '52 Davis Street' as Address line 2; a roadside mail box location, such as 'RMB 725, Princes Highway'; or using a descriptive landmark, such as or 'Corner of Smith & Brown Streets' or 'Second house north of the general store with the red door'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the lowest level locality that contains the address.

annotations.comment: For example: suburb, town, city, settlement, village, or community. Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Fitzroy'; 'Manchester'; 'Kingston' or 'Bergen'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of a local government district or geographical area that contains the address.

annotations.comment: Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Surf Coast' and 'Yarra' local government councils in Victoria, Australia;and the Parishes of 'Saint Andrew' and 'Kingston' in Jamaica..

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of a major government district or geographical area that contains the address.

annotations.comment: Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'New South Wales' and 'Queensland' in Australia; 'British Columbia' and 'Nova Scotia' in Canada; and the Counties of 'Cornwall', 'Middlesex' & 'Surrey' in Jamaica.

localizedDescriptions.en: The code for a postal delivery area containing the address, as defined by the relevant postal delivery service.

annotations.comment: Also known as a postcode or ZIP code.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the country containing the address.

annotations.comment: For example: Australia; Canada; Jamaica; or Norway. Coding with an external terminology, such as EN ISO 3166–1 Alpha 2 country code, is recommended.

localizedDescriptions.en: The type of address.

annotations.comment: For example: physical or postal.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the address not captured in other fields.
Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used inside an organisation cluster.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Type of name described.

Care team details aligned with FHIR resource.
Identifier details aligned with FHIR resources or data types.
The identifier value.
The current state of the care team.
The current status of the care team is proposed.
The current status of the care team is active.
The current status of the care team is suspended.
The current status of the care team is inactive.
The current status of the care team is entered in error.
Identifies what kind of team. This is to support differentiation between multiple co-existing teams, such as care plan team, episode of care team, longitudinal care team.
The care team category is event.
The care team category is encounter.
The care team category is episode.
The care team category is longitudinal.
The care team category is condition.
The care team category is clinicial research.
A label for human use intended to distinguish like teams.

annotations.comment: E.g. the "red" vs. "green" trauma teams.

localizedDescriptions.en: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.

The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care team.
Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary care physician", "Trained social worker counselor", "Caregiver", etc.
Practitioner details aligned with FHIR resource.
Whether this practitioner's record is in active use.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Type of name described.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the address not captured in other fields.
Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
The practitioner gender is male.
The practitioner gender is female.
The practitioner gender is other.
The practitioner gender is unknown.
Practitioner role details aligned with FHIR resource.
Roles which this practitioner may perform.
Specific specialty or specialties of the practitioner.
The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.
The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s).
The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.

The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
Comments made about the participant.
Describes why the care team exists.
An entity comprising one or more people and having a particular purpose.

annotations.comment: For example: a company, institution, association, network, department, community group, healthcare practice group, payer/insurer, care team, or a group of neighbours who provide care or support.

localizedDescriptions.en: The unstructured name or label for the organisation.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Royal Children's Hospital'; 'ABC District Nursing Service'; 'YNWA Oslo' or 'JB Smith Lawyers'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identifier associated with the organisation.

annotations.comment: Occurrences for this data element is set to 0..* to allow for more than one Identifier to be recorded. Note that the ID data type contains multiple subcomponents for recording the ID value, type, issuer and assigner.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identifier associated with the organisation.
Identifier associated with the organisation.
The relationship or role of the organisation to the individual or subject of care.

annotations.comment: For example: oncologist; palliative care home nursing service; or informal support network.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the organisation not captured in other fields.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A framework to communicate the preferences of an individual for future medical treatment and care.
The type of advance care directive.

annotations.comment:
A short text description of the nature of the advance care directive. Coding of the type of directive with a terminology is preferred, where possible. It is expected that this is largely localised to reflect local policy and legislation.

For example, in the Netherlands, advance care directive types include, but are not limited to, 'Treatment prohibition', 'Treatment prohibition with completion of Completed Life', 'Euthanasia request' and 'Declaration of life'.

In the UK, advance care directive types include 'Advance Decision', 'Advance Directive' and 'Advance Statement'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The status of the advance care directive.

annotations.comment: Coding of the advance care directive status with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall advance care directive.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the complete advance care directive, which may or may not be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en:
The conditions or situations in which the individual wishes the advance care directive to apply.

{als toegestaan= Ja, maar met beperkingen (JA_MAAR)}

annotations.comment:
For example: dementia, brain injury, diseases of the central nervous system, and terminal illness. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

The advance care directive applies to all specified conditions if the individual can no longer make or communicate decisions about their medical treatment and is unlikely to regain the ability to make such decisions. Details of specific decisions that apply to different conditions or situations can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Directive details' slot.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the advance care directive not captured in other fields.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for this advance care directive.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the valid period of time for this advance care directive.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: Information about the physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Physical or digital location of the Advance care directive.
Contacts for patients and organisations (excluding practitioners).
The relationship between the subject and the contact. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used for patient contacts, not for organisation contacts.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Indicates a purpose for which the contact can be reached. This field is only appropriate when the archetype is used inside an organisation cluster.
Gender details for the contact.
The contact's gender is male.
The contact's gender is female.
The contact's gender is other.
The contact's gender is unknown.
Date and time when contact detail starts to be valid.
Date and time when contact detail stops being valid.
Organ donation preferences.
Statement whether the subject is on the NHS Organ Donor register.
Subject's preference regarding organ donation.
The subject has explicitly opted in to donate their organs.
The subject has explicitly opted out from organ donation.
The subject has not stated whether they wish to donate their organs or their preference is not known.
Statement whether the subject wishes to donate all organs.
Description of which organ or organs the subject wishes to donate.
The subject wishes to donate their kidneys.
The subject wishes to donate their heart.
The subject wishes to donate their liver.
The subject wishes to donate their pancreas.
The subject wishes to donate their small bowel.
The subject wishes to donate their lungs.
The subject wishes to donate their corneas.
The subject wishes to donate tissue.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Anticipatory decisions about the overall intent of care and possible interventions (including treatments, activities, and diagnostic or therapeutic procedures), asserted by a clinician.
The overall intent for future care and treatment for the individual.

annotations.comment:
The proposed value set is based on the MJA reference. 
Coding the intent of care with an external terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The condition is curable; all appropriate life-prolonging treatment will be offered.
The condition is treatable with potential for restoration to the previous state of health or a prolonged remission; all appropriate life-prolonging treatment will be offered.

The condition is incurable and progressive; active treatment of the underlying disease may be appropriate for specific symptom relief and/or short term life expectancy gains; focused on comfort, quality of life and dignity. Also referred to as 'Palliative'.
Life expectancy is short (hours or days); no active treatment of the underlying disease or treatment-related harm; focus on comfort, quality of life and dignity.
The intent of care decision is not known.
Narrative description about the logic and justification for the 'Intent of care' decision.
Narrative description about all advance intervention decisions, including the CPR decision.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative overview of the advance intervention decision that reflect the specific circumstances for the individual. This includes any limitations, or conditional circumstances applicable, to interventions. This description may or may not be supported by structured data, recorded using the ‘Per intervention’ cluster. If both this narrative description and ‘Per intervention’ structured data is recorded, caution is required as there is a potential risk of divergence. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.

localizedDescriptions.en: Decision about the extent of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) intervention appropriate for this individual.
All appropriate cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted to save or prolong life.
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted, as specified in the 'Decisions description' narrative or as structured data in the 'Per intervention' cluster.

No cardiopulmonary resuscitation treatments should be attempted to save or prolong life. Also known as 'Do not resuscitate (DNR)'; 'Do not attempt resuscitation (DNAR)'; 'Not for resuscitation (NFR)' or similar.
The CPR decision is not known.
Details of the decision about possible treatments or activities that may be life-saving, life-prolonging or cause undesirable side effects.
Name of the possible treatment, procedure or activity.

annotations.comment: While this archetype is intended for all clinical decisions about possible future interventions, the proposed DV_CODED_TEXT value set for the 'Intervention' data element is deliberately not intended to be exhaustive. Instead it has been designed to be inclusive of most of the common life-saving treatments within an emergency context. The alternate choice of the DV_TEXT option can be used to add a local value set or bind to an alternative external value set within a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: Technique used to manually pump blood around the body during a cardiac arrest.
Use of electric shock to reset the electrical state of the heart.
Placement of a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway, including a tracheostomy.
Artificial ventilation where invasive means are used to assist or replace spontaneous breathing.
Artificial ventilation where non-invasive means are used to assist or replace spontaneous breathing.
Insertion of a peripheral intravenous line.

list.label: Central venous line or any arterial line

localizedLabels.en: Central venous line or any arterial line

localizedDescriptions.en: Insertion of a central venous line or any arterial line.
Maintenance of hydration by means other than eating or drinking.
Provision of nutrients by means other than eating or drinking.
Medications used during an emergency resuscitation to prolong life. For example: adrenaline, atropine, sodium bicarbonate, calcium, other vasoactive medications.
Medication that supports heart function, including but not limited to: vasopressors, inotropes and chronotropes.
Medications to treat infections.
Therapeutic substance prepared from human blood including, but not limited to: whole blood; blood components; and plasma derivatives.
Insertion of a tube into the pleural space.
Insertion of an artificial pacemaker to control the heart beat.
Process of removing excess water, solutes, and toxins from the blood.
Transfer to hospital for assessment or admission.
Transfer and admission to an intensive care or high dependency unit.
Decision about the identified intervention.
The intervention is recommended.
The intervention is recommended only in specific circumstances, captured using the 'Preconditions' data element.
The intervention is not recommended.
The intervention decision is not known.
Description of the circumstance/s in which a 'Conditional recommendation' is applicable.

annotations.comment: This data element is only relevant if the 'Conditional recommendation' option is selected in the 'Decision' data element. For example:' "Transfer to hospital is only applicable in the circumstances where the individual suffers a fracture and requires immobilization for pain relief.#

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the intervention decision, not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the justification or rationale for the intervention decision.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about awareness of the Advance intervention decisions by the individual.

annotations.comment: For example: the capacity of the patient to understand the decisions.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about awareness of the Advance intervention decisions by family, carers or legal proxy.

annotations.comment: For example: the individual has no family.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about all advance intervention decisions, not captured in other fields.
The date and/or time when the Advance intervention decisions were last updated.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for the Advance intervention decisions.
The date/time that marks the conclusion of the valid period of time for the Advance intervention decisions.

annotations.comment: 'Valid period end' may often overlap with 'Review due date'. However, they may need to be recorded separately in circumstances where a document has an extended period of validity but requires an interim review. That may be due to changed personal circumstances/events or local policy.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when review of the Advance intervention decisions are due.
Information about the physical or digital location of the advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.
Physical or digital location of the Advance intervention decisions record.

The advance recommendation as to whether cardio-pulmonary resuscitation should be undertaken or not. This is generally referred to in UK clinical guidance as the CPR (Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation) decision.
The advance recommendation as to whether cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) should be attempted. In some cases a clear answer may not be available to the recording clinician.

list.label: CPR attempts recommended adult or child

localizedLabels.en: CPR attempts recommended adult or child

localizedDescriptions.en: Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation is recommended for adult or child.

list.label: CPR attempts not recommended adult or child.

localizedLabels.en: CPR attempts not recommended adult or child.

localizedDescriptions.en: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is not recommended for adult or child.
There is no clear information on the outcome of the CPR decision.
Modified CPR is recommended for child only.
The date at which the CPR decision was originally taken or last reviewed.

children.name: Details for Modified CPR child only
